unit: Unit 2: Balancing Life Between the City and the Countryside

question: What adjective best describes Emma’s physical state?A) Sleepy and loneB) Thirsty and crudeC) Fit (4) and energeticD) Calm and blank

Scientists hope that listening to the whale will help them understand ________. A) Migration patterns. B) How to catch more fish. C) The depth of the local river. D) The best way to build a ship.
The tone of the article regarding the whale's life is mostly ________. A) Sympathetic. B) Hateful. C) Fearful. D) Angry.
What does "lone" mean as used in the title? A) Very heavy. B) Extremely fast. C) Very loud. D) Without others.
What scientific tool helped record the whale's frequency? A) A digital camera. B) A hydrophone. C) A metal ruler. D) A silk net.
The whale’s journey is described as being ________. A) Through a small village. B) Across the city downtown. C) Across vast ocean stretches. D) Inside a dark cave.
Which factor made the whale’s situation difficult for others to understand? A) Its unique color. B) Its large size. C) Its fast swimming. D) Its unusual song.
Tracking the whale for many years required ________. A) No effort at all. B) Constant monitoring and patience. C) Changing the whale’s path. D) Using a very small map.
The story suggests that being "different" in a community can lead to ________. A) Isolation. B) More friends. C) Higher income. D) Greater speed.
What was the specific frequency of the whale’s song? A) 10 Hertz. B) 20 Hertz. C) 52 Hertz. D) 100 Hertz.
Scientists realized the whale was still alive when they ________. A) Found a new recording. B) Saw it at the docks. C) Caught it in a net. D) Asked local fishermen.
What is the main theme of Unit 20? A) Ship design. B) Traditional music. C) Professional growth. D) Individual uniqueness.
The whale's isolation is a "curious case" because it ________. A) Is an anomaly in nature. B) Is very easy to solve. C) Happens to every whale. D) Only lasts for one day.
How did the public feel about the lone whale? A) They were bored. B) They were confused. C) They were fascinated. D) They were angry.
What event led to the need for rebuilding? A) A royal wedding. B) A school holiday. C) A new law. D) A sudden crisis.
Who is the "Hero" described in the article? A) A local volunteer leader. B) A visitor from overseas. C) A famous actor. D) A wealthy banker.
What was the primary goal of the rebuilding project? A) To build a new castle. B) To restore the community. C) To sell new cars. D) To win a prize.
How did the Hero encourage the townspeople? A) By bossing them around. B) By ignoring their fears. C) By offering hope and direction. D) By charging a high fee.
The rebuilding process was described as ________. A) Simple and fast. B) A communal effort. C) A solo task. D) A total failure.
Which tools were likely used during the project? A) Pencils and paper. B) Flutes and drums. C) Spoons and forks. D) Hammers and nails.
What was the emotional impact of the project? A) It fostered unity. B) It created hatred. C) It made people sleepy. D) It led to arguments.
Why did the Hero prioritize the most vulnerable citizens? A) To earn more money. B) To become famous. C) Out of a sense of duty. D) Because they were rich.
The "Hero" prided themselves on ________. A) Their fast motorcycle. B) Their new clothes. C) Their ability to help others. D) Their fancy restaurant.
What was a major challenge during the restoration? A) Having too much help. B) Limited resources and time. C) The weather was too hot. D) The town was too large.
How did the Hero communicate with the volunteers? A) By giving clear instructions. B) By sending secret letters. C) By staying silent. D) By shouting loudly.
The project’s completion was celebrated with ________. A) A long sleep. B) A silent meeting. C) A trip to the city. D) A community feast.
What trait best describes the Hero? A) Greedy. B) Dishonest. C) Lazy. D) Selfless.
Which resource was most valuable for rebuilding? A) Expensive silk. B) Teamwork and resilience. C) Large quantities of gold. D) Ancient maps.
The story teaches that true heroes are found ________. A) During times of crisis. B) Only in movies. C) In royal palaces. D) Near the ocean.
What was the social result of the rebuilding? A) People moved away. B) The town became lonely. C) Social bonds became stronger. D) The town council closed.
The Hero’s strategy involved ________. A) Using traditional methods. B) Focusing on modern trends. C) Moving to a new flat. D) Buying new furniture.
How did the Hero handle disagreements? A) By listening to all opinions. B) By ignoring the problem. C) By punishing those who argued. D) By leaving the meeting.
Rebuilding the houses was a sign of ________. A) Greed. B) Fear. C) Failure. D) Progress.
The "Hero of Rebuilding" is a model for ________. A) Professional athletes. B) Marine biology. C) Community leadership. D) Space travel.
What does "job-hopping" mean in this unit? A) Working at a farm. B) Changing jobs frequently. C) Having no job at all. D) Staying at one job forever.
Why did the main character transition between roles? A) They were often fired. B) They were looking for a high fee. C) To seek new challenges. D) To move to the countryside.
Modern labor trends suggest that job-hopping is ________. A) Illegal in most cities. B) Only for teenagers. C) Very rare and dangerous. D) Becoming more common.
What was the character searching for in their journey? A) Personal fulfillment. B) A large castle. C) A shorter work day. D) A free uniform.
Which skill is most important for a "job-hopper"? A) Cooking noodles. B) Driving a motorcycle. C) Professional adaptability. D) Drawing straight lines.
How did the character's perspective on work change? A) They stopped caring. B) They valued growth over stability. C) They wanted to retire early. D) They became very greedy.
What was a risk of the character’s journey? A) Periods of financial instability. B) Becoming too famous. C) Having too many skills. D) Finding a dream job.
Every new job provided a chance to ________. A) Meet a royal family. B) Stay in a hotel. C) Go on a vacation. D) Broaden their network.
How did employers react to the character's diverse background? A) They were always confused. B) They were angry. C) They were bored. D) They were often impressed.
The "Journey" represents the social science theme of ________. A) Career mobility. B) Ancient history. C) Marine isolation. D) Traditional farming.
What helped the character succeed in new roles? A) Being a fast runner. B) Transferable skills. C) Buying new clothes. D) Having many snacks.
The character realized that every job was a ________. A) Waste of energy. B) Source of fear. C) Learning opportunity. D) Social burden.
How did the character handle the stress of change? A) By sleeping all day. B) By focusing on their goals. C) By arguing with friends. D) By ignoring the future.
What was the main motivator besides salary? A) Meaningful work. B) A fancy office. C) A company car. D) Free food.
The "Job-Hopping Journey" ends with the character ________. A) Finding their passion. B) Moving to the wild. C) Quitting work forever. D) Becoming a student.
What does the character's resume show after several years? A) A lack of focus. B) Only one skill. C) A diverse skill set. D) No progress at all.
The transition between jobs was described as ________. A) A simple walk. B) A dull routine. C) A royal duty. D) A strategic path.
What social impact does job-hopping have? A) It destroys communities. B) It promotes innovation. C) It makes people lonely. D) It stops all progress.
Young workers are encouraged to be ________. A) Open to change. B) Afraid of the future. C) Very quiet and shy. D) Greedy for money.
In the end, the journey was considered a ________. A) Mistake. B) Disaster. C) Success. D) Dream.
What was the core objective of the "Day of Running"? A) To promote community health. B) To catch an animal. C) To test a new road. D) To sell expensive shoes.
Who was invited to participate in the race? A) Only professional runners. B) Only people from downtown. C) Only the town officials. D) The entire community.
Where did the community event take place? A) Inside a dark cave. B) In a royal palace. C) Along the town streets. D) In a deep river.
What was the atmosphere during the event? A) Hateful and angry. B) Energetic and social. C) Quiet and lonely. D) Sad and dull.
How did the event foster social cohesion? A) By making people work alone. B) By charging a high fee. C) By ignoring the participants. D) By encouraging interaction.
Running was portrayed as ________. A) A shared social experience. B) A dangerous task. C) A royal duty. D) A source of income.
What happened at the water stations? A) People were punished. B) Volunteers supported runners. C) Only officials could drink. D) The race stopped forever.
What was the main challenge for the runners? A) A lack of shoes. B) The snowy weather. C) Maintaining their pace. D) Finding the finish line.
The event is a social science example of ________. A) Environmental isolation. B) Career transitions. C) Collective activity. D) Traditional farming.
How did the town officials support the race? A) By staying at home. B) By ensuring safety. C) By selling the results. D) By closing the park.
Participants felt a sense of ________ after finishing. A) Achievement. B) Fear. C) Anger. D) Boredom.
The "Day of Running" parallels which previous unit? A) Unit 1. B) Unit 3. C) Unit 10. D) Unit 6.
What role did children play in the event? A) They watched quietly. B) They participated excitedly. C) They worked at the hotel. D) They drew the map.
Which trait was most evident in the crowd? A) Community spirit. B) Greedy behavior. C) Extreme laziness. D) Fear of others.
The race path was described as ________. A) Very short and narrow. B) Through a dark tunnel. C) Inside a small flat. D) Through the town square.
What was the reward for the winners? A) A large cash prize. B) A new motorcycle. C) Recognition and medals. D) A trip overseas.
Social science views such events as ________. A) A waste of time. B) Tools for unity. C) Royal ceremonies. D) Simple routines.
How did the event end? A) With a big argument. B) With a sudden storm. C) With a festive gathering. D) With a lonely walk.
The "Day of Running" encouraged a ________ lifestyle. A) Passive. B) Healthy. C) Secret. D) Wealthy.
What was the primary lesson of the unit? A) Teamwork leads to success. B) Running is for elites. C) Cities are too loud. D) Speed is everything.
What is the central discovery in Unit 24? A) A new food source. B) A secret map. C) An individual’s skill. D) A rare animal.
Why was the talent described as "hidden"? A) It was illegal to use. B) The character was shy. C) It was too expensive. D) It was in a cave.
How did the community react to the revelation? A) They were confused. B) They were angry. C) They were jealous. D) They were supportive.

The revelation of the talent led to ________. A) More stress. B) A loss of friends. C) Greater confidence. D) Leaving the town.
Unit 24 suggests that everyone has ________. A) Hidden potential. B) A royal background. C) A lot of money. D) A secret enemy.
How did the character feel after sharing their talent? A) Ashamed. B) Proud. C) Tired. D) Fearful.
The talent was eventually used to ________. A) Help the community. B) Make a profit. C) Win an argument. D) Ignore the rules.
Talent recognition is seen as a way to ________. A) Cause conflict. B) Stop progress. C) Move downtown. D) Empower individuals.
Which word best describes the discovery? A) Hateful. B) Inspiring. C) Dull. D) Royal.
The character’s friends played a role by ________. A) Ignoring them. B) Hiding the talent. C) Offering encouragement. D) Stealing the idea.
What was a hurdle to revealing the talent? A) Fear of judgment. B) A lack of tools. C) A physical wound. D) A high city fee.
The "Hidden Talent" is a symbol of ________. A) Social innovation. B) Career mobility. C) Collective fear. D) Personal growth.
The town became more vibrant because of ________. A) New buildings. B) Individual contributions. C) A sudden storm. D) Traditional laws.
What does the story teach about community? A) It should be quiet. B) It thrives on diversity. C) It is for officials only. D) It is very expensive.
The character’s life changed by ________. A) Becoming a leader. B) Moving overseas. C) Finding a hero. D) Buying a car.
Talent discovery is an ________ process. A) Easy. B) Ongoing. C) Illegal. D) Boring.
The unit ends with a message of ________. A) Hope. B) Fear. C) Sadness. D) Silence.
A "Hidden Talent" can become a ________. A) Source of income. B) Royal secret. C) Communal asset. D) Personal drag.
What does the "Standard" represent in this unit? A) A large flag. B) A type of ship. C) A common tool. D) Social norms and rules.
Why did the characters want to "break" the standard? A) To improve things. B) To cause a crisis. C) To save money. D) To be greedy.
Breaking a standard requires significant ________. A) Shyness. B) Courage. C) Laziness. D) Fear.
How did the innovation impact the town? A) It caused failure. B) It led to progress. C) It created isolation. D) It made people angry.
Non-conformity in this unit is seen as ________. A) A mistake. B) A positive force. C) A royal duty. D) A dark secret.

What was the risk of challenging the rules? A) Social rejection. B) Finding treasure. C) Gaining a prize. D) Moving to a flat.

How did the community eventually react? A) They left the town. B) They accepted the change. C) They were bored. D) They asked for a fee.
Breaking the standard is a step toward ________. A) Growth. B) Failure. C) Darkness. D) Silence.
The character who "broke" the standard was ________. A) A lone figure. B) A town hero. C) A greedy worker. D) A royal official.
Which trait helped the innovation succeed? A) Persistence. B) Fearfulness. C) Hatred. D) Sleepiness.
This unit teaches students to be ________. A) Quiet followers. B) Change makers. C) Greedy leaders. D) Passive readers.
The "Standard" was like a ________ to progress. A) Bridge. B) Ceiling. C) Gift. D) Map.
Social science encourages us to ________. A) Ignore the facts. B) Question the standard. C) Move to a cave. D) Be very dishonest.
What was the resulting future for the town? A) Sadder. B) Brighter. C) Darker. D) Shorter.
Innovation is presented as ________. A) Necessary. B) Dull. C) Hateful. D) Simple.
The new standard became a ________ for others. A) Burden. B) Problem. C) Secret. D) Model.
The final message of Unit 25 is ________. A) Embrace progress. B) Stay traditional. C) Work alone. D) Avoid all risks.
